posts.name: Mohammad Awwad
posts.cooked:
We are currently the MK3 all falcon standard gear ration for swerve drive specialist, we have programmed it using the sds swerve drive library. We have done everything according the docs. I have attached some videos where you can see our robot drift quite a but by simply going back and forth, and the bigger problem we are facing is when rotating and moving in any direction, it almost begins to pivot on one module rotating around its self. We aren’t sure what the problem is and have dine everything according to the sds template. I have also attached a video of our modules as they move in all directions near the end is when we rotate and go forward at the same time. Thanks for any help in advance!

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1XxSsy8QRLnJm7wogKuUK-ewoeOgp_ZIP/view?usp=drivesdk

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Y2byu3CS7ff6wSukUGQI3mdP5Bld3wEx/view?usp=drivesdk

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Y8IgHwVhwfS_JAwKTlbqWGb2op4T5TQx/view?usp=drivesdk

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked: Are your steering encoders drifting? Did you ensure that you glued them down? Do you have anything in coast mode instead of brake mode?

posts.name: Mathias Petersen
posts.cooked:
Hi, I am also a programmer for the team that made this post.

The steering encoders are not drifting, they are properly secured to the robot and won’t budge, and the rotation is the only thing in brake, driving is in coast. Do you recommend we switch the driving to brake?

By the way, we are using the SwerveDriveSpecialist’s lib for our drive code.

posts.name: Kirk Nguyenle
posts.cooked: Try subtracting your gyro reading from 360, then giving it to  the chassis speeds while driving. My guess is that your robot thinks it’s rotating counterclockwise, when it’s rotating clockwise.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
Some things to try. Output your gyro angle to smart dashboard and see if the reading is consistent with what you are expecting.   Remember counter clockwise is negative.

Verify your geometry for the kinematics.  The number passed in is the offset from center of rotation for each module.  If not defined correctly your center of rotation will not the be the center of your bot. It should look something like this.

Verify the 0 of your wheels.  that is Are they pointing straight forward and parallel (use a straight board) when it is turned on?

Is the gyro coming unplugged from the can or power.   We had an odd problem where the drivers kept reporting that the swerve would switch back and forth between field oriented and bot oriented drive.  It became bot oriented drive when the power was lost to the pigeon (gyro) and the pigeon would be reporting 0 as the angle.

Try the rotation very slowly and see if you have the same center of rotation issue that may tell you if you have a loose connection somewhere.

That is all I have for ideas.  You may also want to post a link to your code in github or post it on here so people can take a look to see if there is a conversion issue somewhere.

You said you used swervelib, did you start with the swerve template?  That is where we started.  IT is pretty good you have to add some more to it to get autonomous information and drive but it is a great start.

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
It’s a little hard to tell what’s going on from the videos, but the video of underneath the robot shows something that might be wrong, if I’m viewing it correctly.  At the end of that video, it appears that you are trying to rotate while moving linearly.  Again, it’s hard to tell, but I don’t think the wheels on the left side of the screen are pointed correctly to do that.  It looks like they are pointed almost directly at the corresponding wheel on the other side of the robot, which I don’t think is correct (i.e., parallel to the nearest wall of the robot).

That could be because of a software problem, where you are instructing the wheel to move to the wrong direction, or a hardware problem where the encoder is giving you false information or the motor is not behaving properly.

When my team is facing a vexing problem like this, I always encourage them to break it down into smaller problems to try to diagnose.  For example:

-Turn each wheel by hand through a few full rotations, and log out the angle being produced by the encoders.  Do they always produce the correct value? -Turn each wheel by hand and make sure that they all turn smoothly. -“Drive” each wheel by hand and make sure they all drive smoothly. -Write some simple test code that directs each wheel to a few test angles (outside of the complexity of your whole code base).  Validate that each wheel behaves as expected. -Write some simple test that directs each wheel to spin forwards (outside of the complexity of your whole code base).  Validate that each wheel is spinning in the same direction and roiligjly the same speed. -In the main swerve code, log out the desired angle of each wheel and the actual angle, perhaps to the smartdashboard.  They should track pretty closely together.

One of these test will likely fail, and then you’ll have something more narrow to focus on fixing.

posts.name: Josh Buker
posts.cooked: Hi vargoose. For the Cancoders, which part do you glue down? We were thinking we had to do that do the magnets underneath?

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
yes! sorry for not being specific, the magnets underneath.

Are you finding that your absolute angles are drifting?

posts.name: Josh Buker
posts.cooked: Yeah, after some driving the wheels change where they view zero to be, so we were thinking it was the magnets moving and we were going to super glue them down, but its good to know that is an actual fix before we ruin a set of mk3s.

posts.name: Josh Buker
posts.cooked: Looks like I need to start reading more manuals. Anyway thank you man. I’m glad I stumbled upon this thread.

posts.name: Mohammad Awwad
posts.cooked: Thanks for all the replies I will run some more tests when I get the chance later today and will get back, thanks again!

posts.name: Mathias Petersen
posts.cooked: When rotating to the right or clockwise our reading goes into the negatives, and the opposite is true for clockwise

posts.name: Mathias Petersen
posts.cooked: from what we’ve seen everything works when in an controlled/isolated environment. Its only when the gyro is introduced is when the problems start to occur, we just are not sure what exactly the problem is. We have tried 3 different gyros, 1 navx mxp produced similar driving result but different rotation results (wobbly rotation and sometimes would switch off field oriented), the 2 navx micro’s we tested act the same but the newer one was considerably more accurate and had lest gyro drift.

posts.name: Mathias Petersen
posts.cooked: they are pointing straight, we have aligned them too many times at this point and verified to the best of our ability that they are straight. I don’t believe that the gyro coming unplugged is the problem, it would sometimes switch off field orientated but not when moving at speeds I would consider fast enough to unplug the gyro’s connection to the roborio. We kind of started with the swerve template, we took the drive train and replaced it with our old code and it has been modified in no significant way other than adding methods for other subsystems/commands or to fit our Constants style. We did test the robot on our old code and it acts the same, we are decently sure it’s a gyro problem but we don’t what exactly

posts.name: Kirk Nguyenle
posts.cooked: So my understanding is that when rotating counterclockwise, you gyro reading is positive, and when rotating clockwise, your reading is negative. Subtract your fused heading from 360. Your drivetrain thinks it’s rotated 180 degrees in the other direction. Thus it’s giving wrong module commands to the modules

posts.name: Mathias Petersen
posts.cooked:
We found a few new issues, in the code for the SDS drive train they subtract 360 from the gyro, we removed that code and the rotation while moving was fixed, but when driving the robot would still drift and rotation slowly. We also noticed that the tire belts screws on our robot were sticking out now, as the track got worn down so we tightened them and that helped with another issue we saw where a few of the modules were lifting off the ground.

So after these chains of issues were solved we noticed that the module are now slightly off. We will be realigning them when we next meet, and we’ll be sure to have them be the best aligned modules anyone has ever seen. I’ll report back with the result after all this. We are also adding locktite to a few screws we noticed were loosening.

Let’s hope we can finally put these issues behind us, at least for a little bit.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
Krik:

So my understanding is that when rotating counterclockwise, you gyro reading is positive, and when rotating clockwise, your reading is negative.

Yes, I misspoke earlier when I said CCW was negative.

posts.name: Mohammad Awwad
posts.cooked: We tried reversing it and it didn’t change anything really it still drifted, we are going to attempt using a pigeon to see if that fixes anything
